references: We use five sub-categories of Amazon datasets1 11 11https://cseweb.ucsd.edu/~jmcauley/datasets/amazon_v2 in our experiments, including “Arts, Crafts, and Sewing” (Arts), “Industrial and Scientific” (Scientific), “Musical Instruments” (Instruments), “Prime Pantry” (Pantry) and “Video Games” (Games). We filter items without titles and items with fewer than four interactions. Tab. 1 presents the statistics of the data. references:
Tab. 2 reports the overall performance of all methods.
Based on the results, we have the following observations:

Variation 1 outperforms LLMRec in Tab. 2, showing that injecting adapters into LLM and fine-tuning adapters with our proposed coarse-grained adaption tasks (semantic alignment and distinguishing hard samples) for sequential recommendation can improve the performance of LLM-based SRS.

references: We train MixRec on a machine with four NVIDIA RTX 3090 GPUs using the AdamW optimizer (Loshchilov and Hutter, 2019). We employ the pre-trained OPT-125M (Loshchilov and Hutter, 2019). We employ the pre-trained OPT-125M6 66 66https://huggingface.co/facebook/opt-125m as the backbone of MixRec base base {}_{\text{base}} start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT base end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT base base {}_{\text{base}} start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT base end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT base base base base base base base base{}_{\text{base}} {}_{\text{base}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT base end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT base end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT and MixRec. OPT-125M is one of the most widely used decoder-only models. By default, we use Neural Collaborative Filtering (NCF) (He et al., 2017) as CF model in (He et al., 2017) as CF model in MixRec. In Sec. 3.4, we will compare the results using different CF models. We set the number of epochs to 40 and choose 5 × 10 − 5 5 superscript 10 5 5\times 10^{-5} 5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the peak learning rate. The warmup strategy adjusts the learning rate during training, with the warmup stage set to the first 6% of all iterations. The maximum item “sentence” length is set to 30. The bottleneck size of the adapter block is 64. For contrastive learning (Sec.  5 × 10 − 5 5 superscript 10 5 5\times 10^{-5} 5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 × 10 − 5 5 5× × 10 − 5 10 10 − 5 − −5 5 5 superscript 10 5 5 superscript 10 5 5 5 superscript 10 5 superscript superscript10 10 5 5 55\times 10^{-5} 5\times 10^{-5}5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the peak learning rate. The warmup strategy adjusts the learning rate during training, with the warmup stage set to the first 6% of all iterations. The maximum item “sentence” length is set to 30. The bottleneck size of the adapter block is 64. For contrastive learning (Sec. 2.2.4), within a sequence, we select one item ( n s = 1 subscript 𝑛 𝑠 1 n_{s}=1 italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 ) as the positive sample and choose five negative samples ( n s = 1 subscript 𝑛 𝑠 1 n_{s}=1 italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 n s = 1 n s n ns s= =1 1 subscript 𝑛 𝑠 1 subscript 𝑛 𝑠 1 subscript 𝑛 𝑠 subscript subscript𝑛 𝑛𝑠 𝑠1 1n_{s}=1 n_{s}=1italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1) as the positive sample and choose five negative samples ( n c ⁢ l = 5 subscript 𝑛 𝑐 𝑙 5 n_{cl}=5 italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 5 ) for that item by default.
